text: RT @ossoff While in Albany, I stopped to honor Horace King. A freed slave, Mr. King was an architect, engineer, and master bridge builder who designed and built major bridges throughout the South. King was elected to Alabama’s state legislature in 1868. He died in 1885 in LaGrange, Ga. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExwZW7EXMAMA_CX.jpg

RT @ossoff Georgians elected me to deliver COVID relief. @SenatorWarnock and I delivered. This week I'm on the road to make sure that help makes it home. I want to recognize all the incredible doctors across GA who have been working tirelessly the past year to help us beat the COVID-19 pandemic. I know I speak on behalf of all Georgians when I say thank you so much for your dedication to GA & our country. #NationalDoctorsDay

When Georgians made their voices heard in January, they made it possible for the #AmericanRescuePlan to become law. I’m glad to be home in Georgia talking about what we delivered to help folks across the state navigate the pandemic. http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1377041435938148356/img/uiVau-rITuRujIYM.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1377041435938148356/vid/490x270/Z3Y8Lg4sCnuU-9dE.mp4?tag=14

The #AmericanRescuePlan helped GA secure millions to strengthen vaccine distribution efforts statewide. Today, with @MayorJohnsonSAV, I toured the Gulfstream vaccination site in Savannah to see the hard work being done to get shots in arms & allow us to safely begin to reopen. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Exwsu8eWYAAp7Lf.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Exwsu8dW8AEPvY-.jpg

Today, I met with the Chatham Savannah Authority for the Homeless to learn more about what they’re doing to combat this injustice in my hometown. I appreciate the important work they’re doing & it’s crystal clear the only solution for homelessness is ensuring housing. 2/2 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExwcgGPWQAkLHNO.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExwcgnKXMAQGwcP.jpg

Housing is an issue very close to my heart & I firmly believe everyone should be able to live in dignity with a roof over their head. Unfortunately, the COVID-19 pandemic has only exacerbated homelessness across Georgia—including for our veteran communities. 1/2 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExwcEV_WQAMr-GY.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExwcMVqXMAoQZuO.jpg

As we round out #WomensHistoryMonth, I want to recognize the countless women in Georgia who are fighting to protect access to the ballot box—past, present & future. Thank you for your willingness to stand up & fight tirelessly for our democracy.

I’ve said it before & I’ll say it again: housing is health care—especially during a pandemic. I’m glad to see important steps being taken to keep Georgia's families safely housed.
https://www.ajc.com/news/nation-world/cdc-extends-covid-eviction-moratorium-to-june-30/AOBI2JLGZNGELOLJJIQS7LFZ2A/

What happened in Georgia with SB 202 wasn’t an isolated incident—we have been seeing an uptick in voter suppression bills nationwide. We must fight back & pass the John Lewis #VotingRightsAct & the For the People Act now.
https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/elections/florida-republicans-considering-new-election-bill-would-effectively-ban-giving-n1262297
In the past year, we have lost over 18,000 Georgians to COVID-19. As we mourn and remember those lost too soon, let’s all commit to safely doing our part to help beat this pandemic.

Glad to be in Savannah today talking to local officials about how we can help get and keep people housed, as well as what’s being done on the ground to help our veterans experiencing homelessness and how the #AmericanRescuePlan will help families keep roofs over their heads.

If you or someone you loved served our nation in uniform and is still in need of benefits, reach out to a Veteran Services Officer: https://nvf.org/veteran-service-officers/
They may be 50 years past due, but these benefits will make an impact on the lives of so many veterans in the Valley and across the nation.

Here’s the news: Starting this year, more than 30,000 veterans who developed Parkinsonism, Bladder Cancer, and Hypothyroidism due to Agent Orange exposure are now eligible for additional VA benefits for themselves and their families.
So I buckled down and I got to work to fix that. Eventually, our team brought together Democrats and Republicans, wrote a bill, built a coalition, and eventually got our policy signed into law.

When I got to Congress, I learned that so many Vietnam veterans like my grandpa were being denied their benefits because the VA hadn’t kept up with the science on what conditions were ultimately caused by Agent Orange.

Growing up, I heard stories of my grandpa’s service in Vietnam. Unfortunately, like so many soldiers who served abroad during the war, he got sick because of service time exposure to the toxic chemical Agent Orange.

Yesterday was National Vietnam War Veterans Day, a day to honor the 3 million men and women who served our nation almost 50 years ago. To commemorate the day, I had the honor of joining veteran leaders in Modesto to announce new benefits for our veterans. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExwD35OXIAMld-5.jpg

$280 million to support mental and behavioral health, prevent burnout among healthcare providers and public safety officers.

$80 million specifically for vulnerable children.

$1.5 billion for comprehensive community mental health services.

$1.5 billion to prevent and treat substance abuse.

Just as we want our allies to focus on comparative advantages rather than merely being a smaller version of the US military, we should want our services to develop unique capabilities that together, form a Joint Force that is greater than the sum of its parts.

But the last thing we need is every service running like moths to the flame to justify their existence based on one mission. It’s great everyone recognizes Indo-Pacom is the priority. It’s overdue. But not every service needs to play an equal role there.

With the Army, and secondarily, the Air Force running point in Europe, that means the Navy and Marine Corps can focus on the Indo-Pacific. Of course, there will be overlap. Army units in Europe should have long-range precision fires, too.

The Army’s primary mission should be Russia. We need to ensure NATO’s eastern flank is strong enough to deter Putin. There’s no faster way to lose focus on China than inviting further Russian aggression in Europe, particularly against our NATO allies.

THREAD ➡️ It’s good to see the Army thinking creatively about its future, but we don’t need to duplicate the Marine Corps’ new littoral defense mission. With inadequate defense budgets looming, it may make sense to divide missions by service. https://www.19fortyfive.com/2021/03/americas-maritime-army-how-the-u-s-military-would-fight-china/

Thank you to @Public_Citizen for their work in shining a light on this issue and on other irresponsible, last minute rules set in place by the Trump Administration

During a pandemic, we can’t divert public health agencies’ resources, time & funding to a pointless bureaucratic exercise such as this with stakes as high as this. By getting rid of the SUNSET rule, our resolution saves government workers time and taxpayers money
The SUNSET rule was an attempt by the Trump Administration to sabotage the incoming Administration and would be detrimental to these agencies and the citizens that rely on their services.
Do you know how many agency regulations they would have to review to ensure that they didn’t unnecessarily expire? 18,000

The SUNSET rule was finalized on the last day of the Trump Administration. It requires the HHS, CDC, NIH, & FDA, among others, to review all their regulations within several years or else the rules will automatically expire.

Yesterday, @RepAnnaEshoo and I introduced a resolution through the Congressional Review Act to overturn the SUNSET rule.

The people of Washington, D.C., want the rights and responsibilities of statehood. They deserve those rights, and there is no just cause to refuse them. Washington, D.C., should be a state.

My piece: https://richmond.com/opinion/columnists/don-beyer-column-washington-d-c-should-be-a-state/article_15b9f643-66d0-5204-b554-caad1f91b0d9.html

There is no defensible logic to barring DC’s entry to the union as the 51st state, a fact that opponents of the measure have made plain by increasingly nonsensical arguments against statehood.

"No car dealerships" is an all-time-low, but their real reasons are much more cynical. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExwggJkXEAcmR7G.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Exwg_S-WEAIR7Qp.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExwhBmpWgAAf1Af.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExwhDwaWgAstZSI.png

Statehood would mean full self-government for Washingtonians, including legislative power, local budgetary control, more authority over the exercise of policing powers and full representation in Congress.

Recent events have shown just how much the District needs these rights: http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Exwfwl_XIAET0Ep.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExwgDnnXMAInIB-.png

“...governments derive “their just powers from the consent of the governed.”

The right to self-determination is the defining principle on which this nation was founded, and yet this very right is denied to those who reside in our nation’s capital."

"Those who reside in the capital city of the greatest beacon of democracy the world has ever seen themselves experience a denial of rights, which we would condemn if they lived in a foreign country.

Thomas Jefferson wrote in the Declaration of Independence that..."

RT @RepJeffries John Lewis told us to never give up.

And never give in.

We will crush voter suppression.

As the debate moves forward, we must commit to restoring our democracy with the #ForThePeopleAct and the #JohnLewisVotingRightsAct. Only then will we give everyone a seat at the table and realize our full potential as a nation. 11/11

Other critical provisions in this bill will limit the influence of dark money and take on corruption. And, as the Kochs have discovered, it’s really popular with people because it ensures power is in their hands! 10/11

Gerrymandering is a practice as old as the republic that has become a science. Republicans have vowed to sharpen their pencils in NH and elsewhere to rig the maps. H.R. 1 would end partisan or discriminatory maps and establish independent commissions. 9/11
We’re also entering a redistricting year where political leaders will work to maximize every advantage possible at the expense of fair maps and competitive districts. 8/11

It shouldn’t take a pandemic (or a blizzard on town meeting day) to realize that we should be making voting easier and more accessible for every eligible voter. H.R. 1 has a number of provisions that accomplish this from automatic registration to early vote. 7/11

What we saw during pandemic voting in NH was a more flexible process that worked. Voters welcome the choice to vote safely from home. And despite being told for years by our SOS that mail in voting would somehow cheapen Election Day, we had a record turnout. 6/11

Our democracy belongs to all of us and is not the property of any one political party. If we’re serious about encouraging everyone to participate and reflecting the views of voters at the ballot box, we have work to do. 5/11

We see hundreds of voter suppression bills pending across the country that seek to suppress the vote. The efforts in Georgia particularly egregious, but this is really the tip of the iceberg. It will continue, fueled by a toxic combination of politics and lies. 4/11
There was a national voter fraud commission that was created as a platform to perpetuate those and other conspiracies, and legislation was passed here that targeted student voters. 3/11

This is a familiar pattern to us in NH. After the 2016 election we were told by President Trump and leading Republicans that the NH presidential and senate elections were stolen by college students and bus loads of people from Massachusetts committing voter fraud. 2/11

#HR1 is groundbreaking legislation that will shore up our democracy against efforts that make it harder to vote and rig our political system. 

These efforts have ramped up since the last election, fueled by GOP conspiracies and the big lie about Biden’s victory. #NHPolitics 1/11

The even larger checks included in the #AmericanRescuePlan, (totaling up to $1,400/person) will help ease the continuing financial hardship on so many households. In March 2021, nearly 79M Americans reported having difficulty paying for usual household expenses during COVID-19.

The number of adults reporting having difficulty paying their usual expenses dropped from 89.7M in December to 80.5M in January, which is still alarmingly high. This is why the Biden Admin. and Congressional Democrats took bold action with the passage of the #AmericanRescuePlan.

BUILD COMMUNITY: I shared last week that I believe the opposite of feeling foreign is to be loved in a community. My mom told me comforting words: “You are never alone. Whatever problems come, let us know and we will go through together.” Community is our sharedness. 10/11 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Exvx5m4W8AQbKRZ.jpg

YOU BELONG/WE BELONG: The words violently hurled at this woman “You don’t belong here” are intentionally meant to draw distance and isolate. Let us commit to overpowering that rising tide of hate by speaking in chorus “You belong. We belong.” This is my family. #WeBelong 9/11 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Exvx8RgXIAwrE_9.jpg

Responding to the pain of others isn’t about charity, it is about responsibility. We have responsibility to those around us, as they do for us. We treat others as we want to be treated. We help others as we hope to be helped in our moments of need. 8/11

IT IS OUR RESPONSIBILITY: The lack of action during the attack and then shutting the door after threat is over speaks less to fear and more to callousness. Closing the door delineates that this is not my world and therefore I don’t need to act. I don’t have responsibility.7/11

IT IS OUR BUSINESS: If we see someone else hurt, it's still our business. Even if doorman didn’t intervene in attack for fear of personal harm, he and others should have checked on woman afterwards. Action is not binary. It doesn’t have to be superhero or nothing. 6/11

It is difficult to talk about bystanders because it’s hard to cast judgment when we weren’t there. Would I have stepped in? I don't know for sure. Instead of coming from a place of hypotheticals/moral superiority, I’m considering principles to recommit to. 5/11

As we grow more siloed, we start to see one another as the “other.” Without sharedness we lose touch with responsibility. What are our responsibilities when we are neither perpetrator nor direct victim? What about when we witness hate or suffering of others with our own eyes 4/11

I feel like this is so metaphorical to the challenges we face as a nation right now. We as a society are having a crisis of empathy. What we are losing is that important sense of sharedness. Whether that is shared experiences, shared truths, shared space, shared identity. 3/11

When that door closes, it sends a clear message. It says I’m not going to help. It says this is none of my business. It says to the woman, you don’t belong in this building; keep your problems outside. It says this is not my responsibility. 2/11 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Exvv9FvWYBAm3nO.jpg
